comments.commentBody:
I am surprised the NYT didn't touch on the past problem of "poverty = black people/welfare moms." This dates back to Ronald Reagan who won with this inaccurate depiction of the poor (as we now see, the majority are white people). Even Pres. Obama has stayed away from it as political poison and had no anti-poverty program (never even heard him address the issue).

Also, the poor are considered unlikely to vote, so why waste time of them. Now all of sudden it appears the poor will actually vote (really?). Doubts about that and their absolute number still make it a possible sub-optimal issue to focus on. Plus it seems to "bring the energy down in the room" for some people who would rather focus on success, growth, opportunity and all that "positive"stuff. The poor as an issue just doesn't poll well (sad but true).

Americans also often want to blame the victim (the poor are that way because they did something wrong and thus they got what they deserve). it is only now that a few people are beginning to acknowledge that we have systems that create poverty and shift wealth and income upwards. Neither candidate has a real deep plan for this (tax increases, desegregation of schools, stronger union and organizing rights). Maybe HRC comes the close, but this is where the trust issue comes in (she, like Obama are too close to the Goldman Sachs crowd).

Well for one thing, it's hard for Hillary to pivot from her promise to broaden Obama's Executive Action to shield illegal immigrants from deportation and then start talking about how she wants to help The Poor.

The Poor are fighting each other for that single dishwashing job, and now they have some additional competition from another 6-7 million people who are willing to do that job for less.

From a 1995 GAO report (link below): "GAO found that: (1) illegal aliens in the United States generate more in costs than revenues to federal, state, and local governments combined; (2) estimates of the national net cost of illegal aliens vary greatly, ranging from $2 billion to $19 billion." http://www.gao.gov/assets/230/221495.pdf

And that was 20 years ago; in the report they estimated 3.5 - 4 million illegal immigrants in the US at that time. Now most reasonable news organizations peg that number at 11 million.

An extra $2 billion would sure go a long way in helping The Poor with job training, increased food security (SNAP benefits continue to be cut), childcare subsidies, etc.

How folly to continue to let people in through the back door while simultaneously wondering why The (American) Poor can't catch a break.
The NY Times, can start by addressing poverty in its articles, instead of assuming all are middle or upper class
The first candidate with a poverty agenda loses.

Permanently deport both the Trump and Clinton families to Canada.

Write-in elected Justin Trudeau as president.

Problem solved.
i note the title of this piece has now changed twice. will there be any note anywhere that this happened and why?

I wish these articles put some dollar figures on being in what welfare and disabled persons actually receive. There is a wide variance from state to state for cash assistance welfare, but Supplemental Security Income which sets the floor for permanently disabled who have not earned sufficient taxable income to rely on regular Social Security Disability is around $700 a month. Available housing subsidies only reach less 25% of those eligible, so if you do not hit the lotto and do not get any help paying for housing, you are left very little, if anything to pay for utilities, toilet paper, phone, etc. The life you are forced to live is not one that would appeal to the critics, even if you don't have work. Yes you would be entitled to Medicare/Medicaid and food stamps, but you still need aspirin and even maybe a movie once in awhile to keep your sanity.

What I don't understand is why a few, and there are very few cheaters, are always cited by the right when the issue of subsidizing the poor is raised.
After you put the real numbers of a realistic budget on a piece of paper, it a wonder how people on SSI don't blow their brains out. I am sure any of those on SSI who were able to trade their lives for the lives of those criticizing them would jump at it no matter how hard they would have work. I doubt you could find one critic who would trade their lifestyle for an SSI recipient regardless of not having to punch the clock.
Welfare recipients are even much worse off.

So, I'm genuinely curious, does the NYT pay everyone on its payroll $15/hour or more?  Does it require its vendors and contractors to do so?  If yes, how has that affected the employees?  The business?

Less than two months before the presidential election, Obama's administration releases these numbers and the NYT editorial board falls for it lock stock an barrel.

The numbers are bogus and everyone with more than two neurons knows it.

Didn't trump unveil a whole plan for working mothers yesterday?

Why isn't that even reported?

Thank you for this. The spirit of this country - the spirit that can be publicly seen - is crippled by its self absorption. Advertising, celebrity, films, songs, self help books, so-called reality television, and much of political speech cater to and cultivate it. How real are the sources of the personal anxiety stirred by these profit seeking enterprises? You folks who are angry with the already inadequate efforts against poverty, I would ask: Do you have enough to eat? Are you warm enough when it's cold? Do you sleep in your own bed? Can you see a doctor when you want to? It can help your spirit to recognize what you do have in this uncertain world. And a few dollars more in taxes, even if some of them don't do the job, aren't loss but a gift to your own sense of decency.

Wordsworth said a great truth: "Getting and spending we lay waste our powers."

Does anyone you know have enough? Odds are that you do.

“The other America has a daily ugliness about it that transforms the buoyancy of hope into the fatigue of despair. In this other America, thousands and thousands of people, men in particular walk the streets in search for jobs that do not exist.” MLK

Working class US citizens should be very angry at Bill and Hillary Clinton and their “Established Mainstream Politicians” who are controlled by their elite the “Clinton Foundation” donors, the elite “DONOR CLASS” campaign contributors, and PACs (foreign and domestic) campaign contributors who paid these politicians to create all of the FREE TRADE laws that economically required that our US STEM manufacturing jobs relocate to foreign nations when US citizens do not agree to work for the same wages that Third World citizens are glad to work for.

The US federal government has therefore economically required that US businesses relocate as many US jobs as possible to third world nations when US citizens refuse to work for third world wages.

Even if the next president repeals or re-negotiates President Clinton’s NAFTA and President Clinton’s PNTR for Communist China, those higher paying (STEM) manufacturing jobs are not coming back to the USA because those US citizens that knew how to manufacture things are now long gone and maybe even dead and buried.

In my opinion, any honest talk about ending poverty has to start and end with moving away from the current economic system of global, exploitative capitalism. How can we talk about ending poverty without first admitting the fact that there never has been, currently is not, and never will be, enough "well paying" jobs for everyone that wants one? Poverty is baked into the system. It is a feature, not a bug. As long as we operate under a system that promotes making money AT ALL COSTS, we will have poverty. Why? Because LABOR is usually the biggest expense for any business. Therefore, business will always seek out ways to cut labor costs. It doesn't matter if that means taking advantage of software, robotics, or low wage workers in China and Mexico. Under our current capitalist system, cutting labor is GOOD because it decreases a businesses operating costs, increases profits and share value. Who cares if some people just lost their means to survive? ABSOLUTELY ZERO CEO's wake up in the morning and ask themselves "how many jobs can I create today?" Or "how can I raise the standard of living for people today?" THAT is the problem. THAT is what all of our leaders need to focus on. How do we move to an economic system that puts the happiness and welfare of people and the sustainability of our only planet first? Until we move to such a system we will ALWAYS have poverty. THAT is the cold, hard truth we need to face.
What use are the poor for ANY candidate?
Neither Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump has a specific anti-poverty agenda.  Here's one - WORK HARDER!

Well, well, the NY Times finally acknowledges that Hillary Clinton has some good proposals for addressing the concerns of the poor, while Donald Trump, despite his "concern" for white men with no college degree with few prospects for jobs paying a living wage.  Nice to hear the Times can still address the facts WHEN IT CHOOSES TO.

I have talked about this in several op-eds and articles I've written regarding Latinos.  Not sure if I would only critique the presidential candidates.  Many leaders of various minority groups, particularly Black and Latino, won't talk about poverty because they believe it makes the group look bad.  Puerto Rican leaders, for example, won't admit that even 3rd- and 4th-generation Puerto Ricans still find themselves in persistent poverty.  They just hide behind the immigrant framework portrayal.
The media is controlling this election.  Come on----ask them about poverty instead of staying mired in supposed email problems.  Ask for Trump's tax returns while you are at it.

As many have noted this editorial baldly contradicts itself, it opens: ”neither Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump has a specific anti-poverty agenda." But after blithering around for awhile in false equivalences and blather it admits: “Mrs. Clinton, to her credit, has ideas on how to improve the lives of the poor”.

This is a C- composition from the "Editorial Board" of the New York Times. I expect better.

It is true though that the whole focus of this election is the discontents of the white not-poor-but-downwardly-mobile; Trump captured this zeitgeist and has run with it. It is unfortunately obvious that this mood doesn't care about the poor at best, and many see the issues in racist terms, even though the numbers of destitute whites exceed those of blacks and browns combined.

The penultimate sentence, "Turning those ideas into law, however, will require broad support from the public and Congress," is the problem.

Let me rewrite this editorial concisely:

"Mr. Trump doesn't care a rat's rear end about the poor. Mrs. Clinton does, but has not made it the centerpiece of her campaign. Any further progress will depend on Congress -- it is imperative for many reasons to break the Republican control of Congress."

Affordable housing is never mentioned.

We have a housing crisis. Millions pay half of their incomes for housing. This is money that cannot be spent elsewhere.

We need another New Deal-scale initiative in housing.

Sure, I'd love to help the poor.

But I'd also like to help myself get a house and pay off my school debt, first.

Although this is a crucial topic, it seems ironic for the New York Times to be faulting the lack of discussion.

After all, it is the New York Times that each week, in its Real Estate section, cheerfully describes the luxury development and the wealthy individuals who are displacing low-income and middle-income New Yorkers, at a tsunami pace.

And it was the New York Times which was mostly unquestioning in former Mayor Bloomberg's policies which resulted in the loss of affordable housing in NYC, the significant rise in homelessness and a demographic "cleansing" of NYC where the wealthy of all ages are favored over those who are less glossy and less income.
Freedom includes the freedom to fail and be poor.  It's my or the government's (with my money) responsibility to do a darn thing about it.
Observing situations while very poor get many government e while it is th near poor that has it worse because they don't qualify.

The Democrats talk about government programs to help the poor.

What does that even mean.

People are supposed to help themselves.

Before all the poverty programs, families managed to survive, even in the depression.

Surviving is a learned art just like owning a house.

All the government programs do is to keep them dependent.

What everyone needs and Trump is offering is a real dedication to bringing back jobs and giving people dignity and self-worth through having a job.
